bioghist.p: James Renwick (1792-1863) was an English-American scientist and engineer. Renwick graduated from Columbia College in 1807. In 1820 he was appointed professor of chemistry and physics in that college, a position he held until 1854. In 1838 he was appointed by the U.S. government one of the commissioners to explore the line of the boundary, then settled by the Webster-Ashburton Treaty, between Maine and New Brunswick. In addition to his collegiate duties he wrote the biographies of Robert Fulton, David Rittenhouse, and Count Rumford, in Sparks's American Biography; a Memoir of DeWitt Clinton (1834); and a Treatise on the Steam-engine (1840-1841). His textbooks, Outlines of Natural Philosophy (1832), and Outlines of Geology (1838), were the first works of their kind published in the United States, and, with his other educational works, have passed through numerous editions. Renwick died in 1863. His son, James Renwick, Jr. (1818-1895), was a successful 19th century architect.

scopecontent.p: This is a collection of the papers of James Renwick. Materials include: correspondence, notes,and accounts, of James Renwick, Sr. (1827-1839); nine watercolors and several pen and ink sketches of landscapes, including views of Lake Johnson and the St. Lawrence, possibly by James Renwick; a plan for "an improvement in the Steam boiler", undated; and plans for a mill and a crane. The collection also includes two photographs of an unidentified female, a photograph of an unidentified house, and a check made out to Walton C. Whittingham, 1905.

accessrestrict.p: The collection is open for research.
